thread.section_title: The Columbus Dispatch High School Sports Feed
thread.title: golf | Bexley, Fisher Catholic win state titles
thread.title_full: High-school golf | Bexley, Fisher Catholic win state titles | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: golf | Bexley, Fisher Catholic win state titles
text:
On the coldest day of the fall, Bexley and Fisher Catholic were able to reach down for something extra on Saturday to take home their first boys golf state championships.
In the Division II tournament at NorthStar Golf Club near Sunbury, Bexley posted a 10-stroke victory over defending champion Canton Central Catholic as senior Cameron Karmia earned co-medalist honors with an impressive two-round score of 1-under-par 143 (70-73).
The title was emotional for Jim Ryan, who has coached Bexley in track, cross country, baseball and golf spanning some 45 years. His late father, Jack, who coached at Hartley and St. Charles, is the only member of three Ohio coaches halls of fame (baseball, football, basketball).
“Dad never won a state championship, though,” Ryan said. “This is a dream come true. He’d be so proud today.”
Trailing by four shots entering the day, Bexley used a strong overall effort to overtake Canton Central Catholic.
“Except for No. 18, when we gave up eight shots in the opening round, we played some outstanding golf, and we had a feeling when we got off the bus we had a great chance,” Ryan said. “The kids were really loose and confident. After we won the district, we were determined to win the state. In the kids’ minds, nothing was going to stop us.”
Connor Quigley of Dayton Oakwood shot a final-round 67 to share the title with Karmia, the first-round leader. Karmia had two birdies, the most notable coming on the par-5 No. 7 when he hooked a shot into the water, took a penalty stroke and chipped in from 40 yards.
“There are no words to describe how I feel right now,” Karmia said. “I liked our team’s chances of contending, but if you told me at the beginning of the season that I would be state medalist, I’d say you were crazy. This was not one of my favorite courses and still isn’t for that matter. But I was able to pull out two great rounds in not such great conditions. I’ll take it.”
Hunter Roberts (eighth, 156); Josh Meyer (13th, 159); Trevor Binau (16th, 161) and Davis Williams (23rd, 164) rounded out the scoring for the Lions.
Hartley’s Chris Williard finished in a fifth-place tie at 154.
At the Ohio State Scarlet Course, Fisher Catholic scrambled for an eight-stroke margin of victory over Columbiana for the Division III championship.
Although the Irish (323-335—658) scored significantly higher than usual because of the bitter, windy conditions and rock-hard greens, coach Travis Saffell said the team persevered.
“Today went completely different than I envisioned, except the winning,” he said. “The weather and the pressure really took a toll. It really seemed like a war out there all day. I felt like more of a therapist than a coach, convincing the kids to just hang in there and stay composed ... that they were doing better than it seemed.”
Aaron Wood (78-77—155) tied for third and Blake Saffell (74-82—156) was fifth to pace Fisher Catholic. Both are seniors.
“When I came in four years ago as coach, I told these guys we were changing the program and I wanted everyone to commit to becoming a state power,” Saffell said. “This is the culmination of an awful lot of hard work and a dream.”
Mark Schlabach of Berlin Hiland was medalist (151) and Brayden Baldridge of Danville was runner-up, one stroke back. Baldridge was third a year ago.
In the Division II girls tournament at OSU Gray, Liza Weisman of Bexley took fifth with a 79-76—1 55.
sblackledge@dispatch.com
